overview_paragraphs: This WV-focused dataset covers 1950 through 2024 with county-level returns harmonized across multiple historical source formats.
Margins are calculated as Democratic minus Republican two-party margin percentage; positive values indicate a Democratic edge and negative values indicate a Republican edge.
Contest narratives below describe first-to-latest statewide movement and identify the counties with the largest absolute margins in the most recent available year.

contest_narratives.description: In attorney_general, statewide two-party margin moved from D12.98 in 1950 to R40.05 in 2024, a 53.03-point shift toward Republicans.
In auditor, statewide two-party margin moved from R51.69 in 1952 to R37.43 in 2024, a 14.26-point shift toward Democrats.
In commissioner_of_agriculture, statewide two-party margin moved from D9.21 in 1952 to R38.28 in 2024, a 47.49-point shift toward Republicans.
In governor, statewide two-party margin moved from D3.09 in 1952 to R32.50 in 2024, a 35.59-point shift toward Republicans.
In president, statewide two-party margin moved from R8.16 in 1956 to R42.69 in 2024, a 34.53-point shift toward Republicans.
In secretary_of_state, statewide two-party margin moved from D7.40 in 1952 to R42.29 in 2024, a 49.69-point shift toward Republicans.
In state_treasurer, statewide two-party margin moved from D14.46 in 1950 to R100.00 in 2024, a 114.46-point shift toward Republicans.
In us_senate, statewide two-party margin moved from D7.24 in 1952 to R42.48 in 2024, a 49.72-point shift toward Republicans.
